drug.name: Molsidomine
drug.description: Molsidomine is an orally active, long-acting vasodilator, which belongs to the class of medications known as syndnones. Interestingly, it is being studied as being a preventive measure in cerebral infarction [A31932].

article.citation: Ehlert A, Schmidt C, Wolfer J, Manthei G, Jacobs AH, Bruning R, Heindel W, Ringelstein EB, Stummer W, Pluta RM, Hesselmann V: Molsidomine for the prevention of vasospasm-related delayed ischemic neurological deficits and delayed brain infarction and the improvement of clinical outcome after subarachnoid hemorrhage: a single-center clinical observational study. J Neurosurg. 2016 Jan;124(1):51-8. doi: 10.3171/2014.12.JNS13846. Epub 2015 Jul 10.

Lorenc-Koci E, Czarnecka A, Lenda T, Kaminska K, Konieczny J: Molsidomine, a nitric oxide donor, modulates rotational behavior and monoamine metabolism in 6-OHDA lesioned rats treated chronically with L-DOPA. Neurochem Int. 2013 Dec;63(8):790-804. doi: 10.1016/j.neuint.2013.09.021. Epub 2013 Sep 30.
Rosenkranz B, Winkelmann BR, Parnham MJ: Clinical pharmacokinetics of molsidomine. Clin Pharmacokinet. 1996 May;30(5):372-84.
Ostrowski J, Resag K: Pharmacokinetics of molsidomine in humans. Am Heart J. 1985 Mar;109(3 Pt 2):641-3.

link.title: Relationship between pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of molsidomine and its metabolites in humans

drug.indication: The indications for use of molsidomine include ischemic heart disease, angina, chronic heart failure, and pulmonary hypertension [L1370, L1371].
drug.pharmacodynamics: Molsidomine leads to smooth muscle relaxation in the coronary blood vessels, relieving symptoms of angina and increasing blood flow to the coronary arteries.
drug.mechanism-of-action: Molsidomine, a cardiovascular drug, acts in a similar fashion to organic nitrates. The SIN-1A metabolite of molsidomine has a pharmacologically active group of nitric oxide, which increases levels of cyclic GMP, and decreases intracellular calcium ions in smooth muscle cells. This leads to relaxation of smooth muscle in the blood vessels, and inhibits platelet aggregation.
drug.metabolism:
Molsidomine hepatically metabolized to _linsidomine_. Linsidomine releases nitric oxide (NO) from endothelial cells when it decays, and acts as the active vasodilating metabolite responsible for molsidomine's pharmacological effects.
Oral absorption of Molsidomine is found to be 95.5% Â±4.5. Presystemic metabolism is noted to be 56% and metabolism is reported extensive by Liver. Renal Excretion accounts for 95 % and plasma half-life is 5 hr. Back to top
drug.absorption: Peak plasma drug concentration (tmax) occurs from 1 to 2 hours after administration.
drug.clearance: renal excretion is the main route of elimination of the metabolites in humans (90% to 95%) About 2% of the ingested drug is excreted unchanged in the urine.

classification.description: This compound belongs to the class of organic compounds known as morpholines. These are organic compounds containing a morpholine moiety, which consists of a six-member aliphatic saturated ring with the formula C4H9NO, where the oxygen and nitrogen atoms lie at positions 1 and 4, respectively.

atc-code.level: Other vasodilators used in cardiac diseases

drug-interaction.description: Molsidomine may increase the hypotensive activities of Avanafil.

drug-interaction.name: Udenafil
drug-interaction.description: Molsidomine may increase the hypotensive activities of Udenafil.

drug-interaction.name: Doxofylline
drug-interaction.description: Molsidomine may increase the hypotensive activities of Doxofylline.

drug-interaction.name: Mirodenafil
drug-interaction.description: Molsidomine may increase the hypotensive activities of Mirodenafil.

drug-interaction.name: Fostamatinib
drug-interaction.description: Molsidomine may increase the hypotensive activities of Fostamatinib.

drug-interaction.name: Patent Blue
drug-interaction.description: The therapeutic efficacy of Molsidomine can be decreased when used in combination with Patent Blue.

article.citation: Kukovetz WR, Holzmann S: Mechanism of vasodilation by molsidomine. Am Heart J. 1985 Mar;109(3 Pt 2):637-40.

polypeptide.name: Guanylate cyclase soluble subunit alpha-2
polypeptide.specific-function: Has guanylyl cyclase on binding to the beta-1 subunit.Isoform 2 acts as a negative regulator of guanylyl cyclase activity as it forms non-functional heterodimers with the beta subunits.

go-classifier.description: positive regulation of cGMP biosynthetic process

polypeptide.name: Guanylate cyclase soluble subunit alpha-2
polypeptide.specific-function: Has guanylyl cyclase on binding to the beta-1 subunit.Isoform 2 acts as a negative regulator of guanylyl cyclase activity as it forms non-functional heterodimers with the beta subunits.

go-classifier.description: positive regulation of cGMP biosynthetic process

polypeptide.name: cGMP-specific 3',5'-cyclic phosphodiesterase
polypeptide.specific-function: Plays a role in signal transduction by regulating the intracellular concentration of cyclic nucleotides. This phosphodiesterase catalyzes the specific hydrolysis of cGMP to 5'-GMP (PubMed:9714779, PubMed:15489334). Specifically regulates nitric-oxide-generated cGMP (PubMed:15489334).

go-classifier.description: negative regulation of cardiac muscle contraction
negative regulation of T cell proliferation
positive regulation of cardiac muscle hypertrophy
positive regulation of MAP kinase activity
